8.text:
We can explain ancient history
as the collective events of

11.text:
past from the time when human
history has been recorded

15.text:
stretching as far as Postclassical
Era or the Middle Ages.

21.text:
The extent of recorded history
is estimated to be around

25.text:
5,000 years which began with
the Sumerian Cuneiform Script

29.text:
which is the oldest ever writing to have
been unearthed from the 30th century BC.

36.text:
Classical antiquity is normally
used to denote the history in the

41.text:
olden days from the starting of
recorded Greek history in 776 BC.

46.text:
This date also seems to overlap the
actual founding of Rome which is 753

52.text:
BC, the beginning of Archaic period
in Greece and history of the romans.

58.text:
The concluding date of the period
is however disputed by historians;

62.text:
some say that the period ended
with the fall of Western Roman

67.text:
Empire in 476 AD (which is
also the most accepted date)

71.text:
while some say it ended in 565 AD with
the death of emperor Justinian I, the

77.text:
cessation of Platonic Academy, the rise
of Charlemagne and the coming of Islam.

85.text:
Ancient history of India
includes the Middle Kingdoms or

89.text:
Classical India from the 3rd
century BCE to 13th century BCE.

95.text:
This period saw the beginning of Satavahana
Dynasty and the fall of the Mauryan Empire.

102.text:
This age lasted for around
1,500 years and ended with the

107.text:
death of the Chola king,
Rajendra Chola III in 1279.

112.text:
India was in its highest bloom during
this era when they had the largest

117.text:
economy in the world and held one
fourth of the world’s wealth.

121.text:
Ancient history of China
was marked with Shang

125.text:
dynasty in 1600 BC and
ended with Qin Dynasty.

133.text:
Ancient history can
be understood by two

136.text:
major sources, source
texts and archaeology.

140.text:
It has taken years of work and study to
uncover these secrets of the ancient past.

145.text:
These books and excavations throw light
upon the ancient way of life, work,

152.text:
food, study, science, art, technology,
culture and so many other things.

158.text:
There are still many secrets of these
civilizations which need to be revealed.

166.text:
The study of prehistoric man or human history
by excavating sites and the study of the

172.text:
artefacts and other things revealed in
these excavations is known as archaeology.

178.text:
It is an effort to restructure
previous human behaviour.

182.text:
There are many important excavations
that have revealed some amazing

186.text:
civilizations and have uncovered some
imperative discoveries, some of which are:

192.text:
The excavations of
Mohenjo-Daro in Pakistan,

196.text:
Lothal in India and
Harappa in Pakistan.

200.text:
The mausoleum of first Qin emperor and
the Terracotta Army in ancient China

206.text:
The majestic pyramids of Egypt
built in around 2600 BC

211.text:
where the royalties of Egypt
lay after their death.

215.text:
The study of the ancient city of
Pompeii, a hidden Roman city which

219.text:
enlightens the historians about the
cultures of Samnites and Etrusans.

224.text:
The city was preserved because
of a volcanic eruption which

228.text:
covered it and kept it safe for
today’s historians to find.

232.text:
The discovery by Sir Arthur Evans
and Minos Kalokairinos of Knossos.

239.text:
Knossos is a Greek reference
for the city of Crete.

242.text:
There were many Roman coins
found scattered in the

244.text:
fields which determine that
the civilization was Roman.

248.text:
The discovery of the beautiful city of
Troy by Heinrich Schlieman in 1868.

258.text:
Excavations remains and
we can grab what we can,

262.text:
but writing are a proof
of what actually happened

266.text:
and most of the ancient history can
be explained from the writings of

270.text:
the historian and authors from the
past who lived during those times.

274.text:
Some of the important
historians whose works are

278.text:
trusted are those of Arrian,
Herodotus, Thucydides,

282.text:
Polybius, Livy, SimaQian, Tacitus, Sallust,
Josephus, Suetonius, and Plutarch.

292.text:
The main difficulty which stands in the way
of studying ancient history is that only

297.text:
a portion of the histories which have
been recorded earlier have endured today.

303.text:
The dependability of the
evidence that is got

306.text:
from these literary works
has to be deliberated.

309.text:
None of the cultures boasted
of literacy among the common

313.text:
class and there were very less
people who could write books.

317.text:
Ancient Greece was the first civilization
to have a methodical way of noting

323.text:
down all the events and Herodotus of
Halicarnassus was the first to start this.

330.text:
Thucydides largely eradicated
heavenly causality in his

334.text:
explanation of the battle
between Sparta and Athens,

337.text:
instituting a rationalistic
element which set an

340.text:
example for succeeding
Western historical writings.

344.text:
He was also the first to
differentiate between

347.text:
reason and instant roots
of an occurrence.

351.text:
Rome was home to world’s
most erudite cultures but

355.text:
numerous works by many
famous historians are lost.

360.text:
For instance, a Roman historian
by the name of Livy, who lived in

365.text:
the 31st century BC penned down
the history of the Roman Empire

369.text:
in 144 volumes which he named AbUrbe
Condita (From the Founding of the City).

377.text:
Most of these volumes were lost, only 35
were found and have been kept safely,

382.text:
though there are small summaries of
the lost volumes which still survive.

387.text:
Only a part of Roman history written
down by the historians survives today.

399.text:
The early settlement of the
alluvial plain of Mesopotamian

403.text:
civilization is known to start
in the late 6th millennium BC,

407.text:
the Ubaid Period through the 4th
millennium in the Uruk period, the

412.text:
Dynastic period till the rise of
Babylon in the 2nd millennium.

416.text:
The economy created surplus
food which could be stored

420.text:
and this helped the people
to settle down in one place.

423.text:
Babylonia was a part of lower
Mesopotamia and the city

427.text:
flourished under Hammurabi who
made an empire by merging Sumer

431.text:
and Akkad and Akkadian later on
became their official language

435.text:
while they used Sumerian
language for religious purposes.

438.text:
A tablet from the rule of Sargon of
Akkad which dates back to 23rd century

443.text:
is the earliest source in which
the name of Babylon is mentioned.

448.text:
In spite of many searches the main
city of Akkad was never found.

457.text:
The world’s oldest civilization Elam
situated in now southwest Iran dates back

464.text:
to 3200 BC and continued to exist till
539 BC according to the written sources.

471.text:
The official language of the
civilization was Elamite.

475.text:
The first empire to have ruled
over Greater Persia was

479.text:
the Archaemenid Empire
followed by Median Empire.

482.text:
The Archaemedian dynasty was the largest
in territory among all the civilizations,

488.text:
had the high population and stretched
over a vast 8 million square kilometers.

493.text:
The northeast of Iran Parthia was gaining
power which was led by the Arsacid

499.text:
dynasty, they also ruled over
Mesopotamia between 150 BC and 224 AD.

506.text: Parthia was always in war with the Romans.

509.text:
The most influential empires
of ancient Persia was Sassanid

512.text:
Empire which achieved the most
achievements during its time.

516.text:
Their cultural influences was across borders
from other civilizations in Africa, India,

523.text:
China and Western Europe which led to
creation of medieval art of Asia and Europe.

532.text:
There are not much sources of
Arabia prior to the rise of Islam,

537.text:
the exploration in the Arabian
Peninsula has not been much and the

540.text:
written sources are restricted to
coins and inscriptions from Arabia.

545.text:
The source of Arabian civilization
is mostly known from sources of

549.text:
other civilizations like Greek,
Persians, Romans and Egyptians.

554.text:
The first written inscription
dates back to 8th

557.text:
century which mentions the
Kingdom of Hadhramaut.

561.text:
Yada’il the King of Hadhramaut’s
name was mentioned in an Old

565.text:
Sabaic engraving, which was an
external civilization reference.

570.text:
The main trade of the civilization was myrrh
and frankincense which was also one of the

576.text:
reasons why the civilization was connected
to the Mediterranean world and East Africa.

582.text:
They also imported ivory from
Africa and sold it to the Romans.

592.text:
Egyptian civilization lasted very long
and was located in northeast Africa.

598.text:
The civilization flourished
beside the fertile Nile

601.text:
River and the farthest stretch
of their civilization

604.text:
is known to be in the 2nd millennium
BC which is commonly referred as the

609.text:
New Kingdom period - from the Nile in
the north to Jebel Barkat in south.

614.text:
The civilization ended in 30 BC when
the Romans captured Ptolemaic Egypt.

620.text:
Egyptian civilization is one of
the best cultures of the world;

623.text:
home to famous pyramids,
the city controlled

627.text:
and balanced the natural
and human resources.

630.text:
They irrigated the Nile valley,
exploited the mineral in the

634.text:
nearby deserts, developed
literature and writing system,

638.text:
organised trade with neighbouring
regions and a strong military

641.text:
system which controlled the lands
and even the neighbouring cultures.

649.text:
Before the Egyptian civilization could
begin the Kushite state was formed in the

654.text:
area, the Kushite civilization is also known
as Nubia and they first rose in Sudan.

660.text:
They mention of Nubia is in Hebrew,
Roman, Greek and Egyptian texts and

665.text:
has been referred to as Ethiopia in
ancient records of Rome and Greece.

671.text:
Many classical writes mention about
how Nubia flourished during its time,

676.text:
as it constituted most of Africa
and some parts of Europe and Asia.

681.text:
The main gods of worship for the
civilization were Amon and Isis, like the

686.text:
Egyptians the Kushites also build pyramids
as the resting place for their kings.

699.text:
The dates for Indus Valley Civilization
have been marked from 3300 BC to 1700 BC,

705.text:
the territory flourished along the Indus
and Ghaggar-Hakra rivers, in Pakistan.

711.text:
The settlements connected
to this civilization have

714.text:
been excavated in Afghanistan
and India mostly.

718.text:
It is also known as the
Harappan civilization

721.text:
when it was first excavated
in Harappa, Punjab.

725.text:
The civilization was uncovered
very recently in 1920’s because

728.text:
of a rail construction which
was happening in the area.

733.text:
The reason for the demise of this
civilization is mainly because

736.text:
of the water which dried up
forcing the residents to move.

740.text:
The civilization had advanced techniques
of handicrafts like seal carving

746.text:
and carnelian products and metallurgy
with tin, lead, bronze and copper.

751.text:
This civilization is famous for their
planned cities and usage of baked bricks.

757.text:
They also had a fabulous
drainage system, water-supply

760.text:
system and many buildings which
were not used as residence.

768.text:
The beginning of this era
is marked by the birth

772.text:
of Buddha and Mahavira
in the 6th century BC.

775.text:
The ancient history of India is
also referred to as the golden

779.text:
age which has been mentioned
in the Sanskrit literatures,

783.text:
and began with sixteen monarchies in 500
BC who were referred as Mahajanpadas.

790.text:
The lands stretched from Afghanistan to
Bangladesh across the Indo-Gangetic plains.

796.text:
Some of the biggest cities were
Kosala, Magadh, Gandhara and Kuru.

802.text:
The famous epics Mahabharata and Ramayana
have their roots set in this period.

808.text:
Among all the Mahajanpadas
the most powerful and

812.text:
legendary kings of all
times was AshokaMaurya.

816.text:
During his rule Chera, Chola and Pandya
were ruling the South whereas the

822.text:
Anuradhapura (now Sri Lankas) was under
the command of King DevanampiyaTissa.

829.text:
These kingdoms were in friendly
terms with the Mauryan

832.text:
Empire to such an extent
that Ashoka sent four monks,

839.text:
novice to Anuradhapur,
after listening to their

842.text:
ways Devanampiya embraced Buddhisn and
encouraged his people to follow Buddhism too.

849.text:
The Satvahanas soon overthrew
the Mauryan Empire

853.text:
after the death the
Kning Ashoka in 232 BC.

860.text:
This period is also known
as the classical age when

864.text:
Gupta Empire unified most
of the North India as one.

867.text:
It was founded by Sri Gupta and the
empire was at its pinnacle in 320 CE.

875.text: There was peace and order during his reign.

877.text:
The rulers encouraged art and science which
lead to many discoveries and inventions

883.text:
in astronomy, art, literature, technology,
mathematics, religion and philosophy.

889.text:
There are many paintings,
sculptures and architectures

892.text:
which are of great beauty
belonging to this era.

895.text:
Many well-known scholars belonged to era
like Aryabhatta, Kalidasa, Vatsayana,

901.text:
Vishnu Sharma and Varahamihira who
advanced in various academic fields.

907.text:
The most noted rulers of the Gupta Empire
were Chandragpta I and II and Samudragupta.

915.text:
The famous poet Kalidasa mentions how far
the reigns of Guptas spread, twenty one

921.text:
kingdoms in India and abroad and included
nations of Hunas, Kambojas and Parasikas.

928.text:
The official language of the people
was Sanskrit and the people residing

932.text:
in the Northern part of the
civilization were known as Prakrits.

942.text:
The first written inscriptions
found in the Chinese civilization

947.text:
dates back to 13th century
BC to the Shang dynasty.

950.text:
The written records have
been found carved on

954.text:
animal bones and shells
also known as oracle bones.

957.text:
The findings prove that the Shang
dynasty existed in two sets;

962.text:
first or the earlier part was
between 1600-1300 BC and

967.text:
the sources are from Zhengzhou,
Shangcheng and Erligang.

973.text:
The second part of the Shang period
contains many oracle bone writings.

977.text:
The Zhou took over the Shang
by the 2nd millennium

980.text:
BC when they began to settle
near the Yellow river.

983.text:
King Wu the ruler of Zhou
with his brother Duke

987.text:
of Zhou defeated the Shang
in the Battle of Muye.

990.text:
In the 8th century many
military leaders wished

993.text:
to gain control and there
were many other people

996.text:
like Quanrong who started
invading from the northwest

1000.text:
forcing Zhou to move their
capital to Luoyang.

1003.text:
This period is referred
to as the Spring and

1006.text:
Autumn after the scroll
called annals which

1009.text:
have important records of birth, deaths,
important ceremonies which took place in Lu.

1015.text:
Zhou flourished in the Eastern part and
many philosophical schools came up which

1021.text:
gave birth to important movements like
Taoism, Confucianism, Mohism and Legalism.

1028.text:
By the end of 5th century BC only
seven important states survived.

1033.text:
These few states always
fought with each other;

1036.text:
hence the name given was
Warring States Period.

1040.text:
Although there was a Zhou
king in the 256 BC he was

1044.text:
simply a king for name
and had very less power.

1052.text:
‘The Book of the later Han’ is a
Chinese book which first mentions

1056.text:
about Japanese people from beyond the
oceans of Luoyang, people of Wa.

1062.text:
According to an old chronicle of Japan
‘Kojiki’ in 660 BC it was Emperor Jimmu who

1068.text:
bought together many tribes of Japan under
one rule and bought order to the nation.

1074.text:
The ‘Book of Wei’ from the 3rd century
writes that around thirty small

1079.text:
states and tribes were united and
ruled by a shaman queen Himiko.

1085.text:
The Chinese travellers to
Kyushu claim that the Han and

1089.text:
Wei Dynasty were descendants
of Grand Count of the Wu.

1093.text:
They have physically described
their looks and said they had

1096.text:
tattoos, braided hair and women
who wore a single piece clothing.

1103.text:
According to the many folklores and
the ‘SamgukYusa’ or ‘Memorabilia

1109.text:
of the Three Kingdoms’, the first
Korean kingdom was Gojoseon.

1114.text:
The founder of the kingdom was Dangun
who was foretold to be a lord of heaven

1120.text:
and have founded Gojoseon in 2333 BC
after which it was ruled by Jizi.

1126.text:
The book ‘Shiji’ also known as the
‘Records of the Grand Historian’

1132.text:
says that Korea was founded in
197 BC by Wiman from China.

1137.text:
Han Dynasty of China ruined Korea and
ruled it for 400 years starting 105 BC.

1145.text:
Later on the three kingdoms
Silla, Goguryeo and Baekje

1149.text:
captured Gojoseon and ruled
the Manchuria Peninsula.

1154.text:
Baekje and Goguryeo being
the most powerful out

1158.text:
of the three failed
many Chinese invasions.

1165.text:
Back in 3000 BC, fifteen
La Viet traditional tribes

1169.text:
joined hands under the
leadership of Van Lang

1172.text:
and formed one dynasty by the
name of Hong Bang to fight

1176.text:
enemies, control floods and
exchange cultures and trades.

1181.text:
Another civilization which
flourished by the Red river

1184.text:
in north of Vietnam delta
was the Dong Son culture.

1188.text:
Archaeological discoveries in
Thailand have lately proved that

1192.text:
bronze culture began in Vietnam
and not in China as they claim.

1200.text:
When Xiongnu established
empire in the 3rd

1203.text:
century BC it marked the
beginning of Mongolia.

1207.text:
Xiongnu was founded by Toumen who
was later on succeeded by his son

1212.text:
ModuShanyu, who conquered and
united many tribes under his flag.

1217.text:
Xiongnu stretched from Lake Baikal in the
north to Great Wall in the south and

1222.text:
from Greater Khingan Mountains in the
east to Tian Shan Mountains in the west.

1231.text:
There have been no records
left by the Huns,

1234.text:
the only mention
about them is in 151

1237.text:
when northern Xiongnu was
overpowered by the Chinese at the

1241.text:
Lake of Barko and they moved
to western steppe at Kangju.

1245.text:
Chinese records of 2nd and 4th centuries
show that a small group of people thrived

1250.text:
on the fragments of Xiongnu was scattered
all over the steppe of Kazakhstan.

1255.text:
The records mention the name
of the tribe as Yueben.

1265.text:
The Cental Andes in South America
has the longest every flourished

1270.text:
civilization for 4,500 which started
from Norte Chico to the Incas.

1276.text:
The Norte Chico flourished beside the
rivers of Pativilca, Supe and Fortaleza.

1282.text:
The Incas started their
rule under Manco Capac and

1285.text:
was the biggest empire in
the pre-Columbian America.

1289.text:
The main city was Cusco which
was the centre of all important

1294.text:
things like political,
military and administration.

1298.text:
The Incas used conquests and peaceful
ways to join South America into one.

1304.text:
Their official language
was Quechua although

1307.text:
there were many
local dialects too.

1313.text:
The main Mesoamerican civilizations
include Mayans and Olmecs.

1318.text:
There were many cultures which rose
between 2000 BC and 300 BC like the

1324.text:
Aztec, Mixtec, Maya, Izapa, Olmec,
Teotihuacan, Purepecha and Toltec.

1331.text:
These civilizations lasted for 4,000 before

1337.text:
These civilizations were
highly developed in astronomy,

1346.text: The Monte Alban was the city of Zapotech.

1349.text:
Although the Olmecs after them took the
writings of Zapotech, the Olmecs have

1354.text:
been credited to be the first civilization
to have developed a writing system.

1359.text:
Mayan inscriptions date
back to 3rd century BC

1363.text:
and have been found in
San Bartolo, Guatemala.

1372.text: The Etruscans developed in Italy in 800 BC;

1376.text:
their history can be tracked exactly
from the artefacts and the burial sites.

1381.text:
Etruscan was a culture which developed
from the tribe of Villanovan

1386.text:
people in Etruria of Central
Italy in the 7th century BC.

1390.text:
There are many evidences
found on burial tombs

1394.text:
which look similar
to the Eubean Greek.

1396.text:
There are more than 7,000
inscriptions which

1399.text:
have been found that
reveal about how

1402.text:
the civilization promoted
aristocratic city state that had

1406.text:
centralized power maintained law
and order across the cities.

1410.text:
Construction of public related works
like roads, towns, irrigation system

1415.text:
and defence system of the town has also
been mentioned in the inscriptions.

1423.text:
The history of Greece
is considered to be the

1426.text:
foundation of western
civilization by many historians.

1430.text:
The Greek civilization lasted
till the rise of Christianity.

1434.text:
There are evidences of usage of tools more
than 100,000 years ago but the earliest

1439.text:
settlements have been considered to be
9,000 years on the island of Crete.

1444.text:
The Minoans civilization has been known
to exist in Crete around 3600 BC.

1450.text:
In 1600 BC Mycenaean civilization
overpowered the Minoans which

1456.text:
lead to a period known as Greek
Dark Ages and lasted till 1600 BC.

1461.text:
The Archaic Period witnessed the growth of
Greek and this era also saw the fall of old

1467.text:
royalties as there was a
lot of reforms in Athens

1470.text:
and a new constitution
was formed in Sparta.

1474.text:
Athens rose when Archaic fell to become a
leading power in the Classical period.

1479.text:
After the Battle of Corinth, the Greeks
came under the rule of Romans in 146 BC.

1486.text:
Greece continued to be ruled by the
Romans until the fall of Byzantine.

1494.text:
Roman civilization grew out of
a handful of agriculturists

1498.text:
in the 9th century BC originated
on the Italian Peninsula.

1502.text:
Romans witnessed a shift of monarchs to
oligarchic public to an autocratic empire.

1508.text:
Many cultures of Rome were
inspired from Greece.

1512.text:
The Western world had great
contributions from Rome in the

1516.text:
fields of art, literature, war,
language and architecture.

1520.text:
Many houses, villas and monuments have
been excavated in the cities of Rome.

1526.text:
The monuments had fountains with bath
complexes, gymnasiums, theatres which

1531.text:
were all supplied by drinking water
connected through miles of aqueducts.

1536.text:
Many monuments also had shops,
libraries, marketplaces and sewers too.

1542.text:
Many western kingdoms like
Italy, Gaul, Hispania etc.

1547.text:
broke from the Roman Empire to form
individual kingdoms towards the

1551.text:
5th century which was one of the
causes of the fall of Roman Empire.

1556.text:
The eastern part of what was left of Rome
was then known as the Byzantine Empire.

1565.text:
The Germanic tribes were people
of Northern European origin.

1568.text:
They moved to Britain
which is present Southern

1571.text:
Scandinavia and Northern
Germany in 5th century.

1575.text:
The initial people have been
classified into three tribes according

1579.text:
to the Bede's Historia ecclesiastic
agent is Anglorum Saxons,

1583.text:
Angles and Jutes and the
historians think there might

1587.text:
be Franks and Frisians
included in them as well.

1591.text:
Bede was an English monk and
renowned scholar and author and this

1595.text:
book earned him the title of
‘The Father of English History’.

1599.text:
The ‘Anglo-Saxon Chronicle’ also mentions
the movement of these tribes to Britain.

1604.text:
The Anglo-Saxon word is
used for the people who

1606.text:
live towards the south
east of Great Britain.

1610.text:
In the later Iron Age, Celts had become
famous and had expanded their lands as far as

1616.text:
Scotland in the north,
Galatia in the east and

1619.text:
Iberian Peninsula and
Ireland in the west.

1623.text:
In the beginning of the
AD when the Roman Empire

1626.text:
expanded and the migration
of Germanics, the

1629.text:
Celtics became limited to
British Isles and by the

1632.text:
1st millennium AD the
Celtic languages died out.

1641.text:
Ancient history witnesses many
new religion and philosophies

1645.text:
all over the world especially
in the 6th century BC.

1649.text:
